Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Nonlinear Magnetization Dynamics Excited by Spin Transfer Torque
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Electric and magnetic properties of ferromagnetic metals interact with each other but the details of these magneto-electric interactions at short (a few nanometer) distances are not well understood. The goal of this Faculty Early Career Development project is to study new regimes of magneto-electric interactions in very small metallic magnetic objects (nanostructures). In particular, this work will investigate how the energy of magnetic waves in ferromagnetic nanowires is modified by an electric current. A new type of magnetic resonance excited by an electric current will be studied, and the feasibility of using this resonance in a magnetic field nano-sensor for the next generation of computer hard drives will be determined. This project will expose high-school, undergraduate and graduate students to nanoscience and will prepare specialists for the US electronics and magnetic recording industries. Nano-electronic devices made for this project will be used in an interdisciplinary experimental skills class at the University of California at Irvine.

****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Understanding collective dynamics of electronic charge and spin degrees of freedom in itinerant ferromagnets is of great fundamental importance and may lead to the development of a new class of magneto-electronic devices. The goal of this Faculty Early Career Development project is to study new regimes of strongly nonlinear magnetization dynamics excited by spin-polarized current in ferromagnetic nanowires and nanomagnets. This work will advance our understanding of how properties of spin waves in ferromagnetic nanowires evolve from linear to nonlinear regimes and how the spin wave dispersion relation is modified by a spin-polarized current. The role of spin wave spectrum quantization on the Suhl instability phenomenon in nanowires will be determined, and a new type of stochastic resonance excited by spin-polarized current will be studied. This project will expose a number of high-school, undergraduate and graduate students to nanoscience and will prepare specialists for the US electronics and magnetic recording industries. Nano-electronic devices made for this project will be used in an interdisciplinary experimental skills class at the University of California at Irvine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This research project resulted in a number of discoveries in the physics of interactions between electrical current and magnetic moment of metallic ferromagnets, some of which have direct applications in spin electronics (spintronics) technology. The work performed in this project resulted in 25 publications in refereed physics journals and in 42 invited presentations at professional meetings, universities, national labs and private industry.

Under this project, we discovered the phenomenon of non-adiabatic stochastic resonance in magnetic tunnel junctions of nanoscale dimensions. The essence of this phenomenon is harvesting thermal energy for amplification of current-driven magnetization precession of a very small magnet. Our work gives the first example of non-adiabatic stochastic resonance in nature. This effect also has practical applications – we have shown that microwave signal sensors based on magnetic tunnel junctions that utilize non-adiabatic stochastic resonance have sensitivity higher than the currently used semiconductor-based sensors. Under this project, we also developed a new type of tunable microwave signal source of nanoscale dimensions – magnetic nanowire-based spin transfer torque oscillator. This type of nanoscale microwave source might find use in wireless communications with microscopic autonomous machines.

We have also demonstrated that microwave-frequency oscillations of magnetization can be induced by microwave voltage rather than microwave current. This discovery has potentially strong impact on the spintronics technology because voltage-driven excitation is much more energy efficient than current-driven excitation of magnetization. We have also demonstrated ultra-fast switching (100 picoseconds) in a new type of computer memory – spin transfer torque magnetic memory (STT-MRAM). This ultra-fast switching was achieved by adding a second polarizing magnetic layer with its magnetization perpendicular to the magnetic layer that is being switched.

Broader Impacts

The ultrasensitive spintronic detectors of microwave radiation developed under this project have higher sensitivity than their semiconductor-based counterparts and hold promise for a new type of spintronics technology. The ultrafast switching of magnetization in STT-MRAM may have strong impact on the development of a new types of computer memory. Several hands-on lab sessions on magnetism and superconductivity developed under this project promoted awareness of science and technology of magnetism among a number of middle school teachers and students, including students from groups underrepresented in science.
